answers.author: Pam Broviak
answers.text:
Suzanne
I have not performed any formal research, but have installed and maintained several sanitary sewer systems built with PVC pipe. And I also have experience maintaining systems built with clay pipe. In about 30 years of working in this field, I cannot think of any failures of PVC sewer piping in the systems I worked with. All of our failures and problems were in clay lines and were mostly due to cracking, roots, and settlement. 
However, proper construction and inspection and testing during installation of both materials is essential to minimize future problems.
You might be able to find additional information about PVC case studies and research here http://plasticpipe.org/ and here http://www.uni-bell.org/index.html

answers.author: Larry Paine
answers.text:
We have been relining our clay/concrete pipe with a "cure in place pipe" or CIPP.  It has been a successful way to replace pipe without having to did a new one in.  Early in my career, I favored the excavation route.  Since I have seen it installed here I have changed my mind.  The chief problem is making sure the right sewer taps are cut!  Coming back weeks/months later to cut a tap is difficult for the vendor.  One advantage of this type of pipe is that it can push broken pieces back into place as it is installed and cured.  What I saw was the liner was heated up with steam and air pressure to "unfold" the liner.  With the air pressure and steam, sometimes the VCP pipe will return to its shape--but not always.
When we did this, we ran a camera down the line and decided whether the pipe needed a point repair or could be fixed with the pressure from the liner.  If we fixed the pipe we still ran the liner through that location.

author: Suzanne Brodine
text: Are there any cities with long-term research on the TCO for PVC sanitary sewer pipe?  Most of the research I have found is from vitrified clay pipe manufacturers; I would like the hear about the experiences of a City that has required PVC and used it for a long period.
title: VCP v. PVC Sanitary Sewer Pipe
